deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The `helmet-csp` package is vulnerable to Cross-Site Scripting (XSS). The `transformDirectivesForBrowser` function in `browser.js` allows for the deletion of the `default-src` Content Security Policy (CSP). A remote attacker can exploit this behavior by removing an application's default CSP, thereby making it susceptible to XSS.

*Advisory Deviation Notice:* The Sonatype security research team discovered that the fix for this vulnerability was actually introduced in version 2.9.2 instead of 2.9.1 as stated in the advisory.
deeperData.detectionMarkdown:
The application is vulnerable by using this component if the `browserSniff` setting configuration is not set to `false`.

Reference: [https://www.npmjs.com/advisories/1176](https://www.npmjs.com/advisories/1176)
deeperData.recommendationMarkdown:
We recommend upgrading to a version of this component that is not vulnerable to this specific issue. If upgrading is not an option, the vulnerability can be mitigated by setting the `browserSniff` configuration to `false`.

Reference: [https://www.npmjs.com/advisories/1176](https://www.npmjs.com/advisories/1176)

deeperData.description: Incorrect parsing of certain JSON input may result in js-bson not correctly serializing BSON. This may cause unexpected application behaviour including data disclosure. This issue affects: MongoDB Inc. js-bson library version 1.1.3 and prior to.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The `bson` package is vulnerable to Untrusted Data Deserialization. The bson serializer does not invalidate unknown `_bsontype` values in objects and proceeds to serialize them as a document, allowing for untrusted data to be smuggled into the data object. An attacker can smuggle data to be serialized/deserialized by any service utilizing bson data.

*Vulnerable File(s) and Function(s)*:

package/lib/bson/parser/serializer.js
* serializeInto()

package/lib/bson/bson_new.js
* serializeInto()

package/browser_build/bson.js
* serializeInto()

package/alternate_parsers/bson.js
* packElement()

package/lib/bson/bson.js
* packElement()

package/dist/bson.bundle.js
* serializeInto()

package/dist/bson.js
* serializeInto()

package/dist/bson.esm.js
* serializeInto()

package/dist/bson.browser.umd.js
* serializeInto()

package/dist/bson.browser.esm.js
* serializeInto()
deeperData.detectionMarkdown: The application is vulnerable by using this component.
deeperData.recommendationMarkdown:
We recommend upgrading to a version of this component that is not vulnerable to this specific issue.

Note: If this component is included as a bundled/transitive dependency of another component, there may not be an upgrade path. In this instance, we recommend contacting the maintainers who included the vulnerable package. Alternatively, we recommend investigating alternative components or a potential mitigating control.

deeperData.description: All versions of bson before 1.1.4 are vulnerable to Deserialization of Untrusted Data. The package will ignore an unknown value for an object's _bsotype, leading to cases where an object is serialized as a document rather than the intended BSON type.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The `bson` package is vulnerable to Untrusted Data Deserialization. The bson serializer does not invalidate unknown `_bsontype` values in objects and proceeds to serialize them as a document, allowing for untrusted data to be smuggled into the data object. An attacker can smuggle data to be serialized/deserialized by any service utilizing bson data.

*Vulnerable File(s) and Function(s)*:

package/lib/bson/parser/serializer.js
* serializeInto()

package/lib/bson/bson_new.js
* serializeInto()

package/browser_build/bson.js
* serializeInto()

package/alternate_parsers/bson.js
* packElement()

package/lib/bson/bson.js
* packElement()

package/dist/bson.bundle.js
* serializeInto()

package/dist/bson.js
* serializeInto()

package/dist/bson.esm.js
* serializeInto()

package/dist/bson.browser.umd.js
* serializeInto()

package/dist/bson.browser.esm.js
* serializeInto()
deeperData.detectionMarkdown: The application is vulnerable by using this component.
deeperData.recommendationMarkdown:
We recommend upgrading to a version of this component that is not vulnerable to this specific issue.

Note: If this component is included as a bundled/transitive dependency of another component, there may not be an upgrade path. In this instance, we recommend contacting the maintainers who included the vulnerable package. Alternatively, we recommend investigating alternative components or a potential mitigating control.

deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `utile` package is vulnerable to Information Disclosure.  The `encode()` and `decode()` functions in `base64.js` utilize the `Buffer()` constructor native to Node.js to initialize blocks of memory when encoding and decoding Base64-encoded strings.  This function, which may be used to process user input, does not ensure that uninitialized memory stored in the `Buffer` object is cleared before it is used in the encoding and decoding process, which may lead to the exposure of uninitialized memory.  An attacker can exploit this vulnerability by sending a request specifically designed to cause the exposure of uninitialized memory, and examining the response.  The response may contain sensitive information including encryption keys, passwords, and other information that could be leveraged by an attacker to execute further attacks.
deeperData.detectionMarkdown: The application is vulnerable by using this component.
deeperData.recommendationMarkdown: There is no non vulnerable version of this component/package. We recommend investigating alternative components or a potential mitigating control.

deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `mongodb` package is vulnerable to Denial of Service (DoS). The `createCollection` function in `db_ops.js` does not properly validate a collection `name` when a database does not exist. A remote attacker can exploit this behavior by specifying an invalid collection name which, when processed by `checkCollectionName`, would crash the application, resulting in a DoS situation.
deeperData.detectionMarkdown: The application is vulnerable by using this component.
deeperData.recommendationMarkdown:
We recommend upgrading to a version of this component that is not vulnerable to this specific issue.

Note: If this component is included as a bundled/transitive dependency of another component, there may not be an upgrade path. In this instance, we recommend contacting the maintainers who included the vulnerable package. Alternatively, we recommend investigating alternative components or a potential mitigating control.

deeperData.description: Directory traversal vulnerability in swig-templates thru 2.0.4 and swig thru 1.4.2, allows attackers to read arbitrary files via the include or extends tags.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `swig` and `swig-templates` packages are vulnerable to Path Traversal attacks. The `fs()` exported function in `filesystem.js` allows user-controlled input to specify the files to be retrieved by the library's built-in file caching mechanism for file re-use. An attacker may craft a malicious swig HTML template that attempts to `include` files that are outside of the application root folder for cached templates by using path traversal characters `../`. Given no file path normalization, this results in Arbitrary File Read.
deeperData.detectionMarkdown: The application is vulnerable by using this component.
deeperData.recommendationMarkdown:
We recommend upgrading to a version of this component that is not vulnerable to this specific issue.

Note: If this component is included as a bundled/transitive dependency of another component, there may not be an upgrade path. In this instance, we recommend contacting the maintainers who included the vulnerable package. Alternatively, we recommend investigating alternative components or a potential mitigating control.

deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `marked` package is vulnerable to Regular Expression Denial of Service (ReDoS) attacks via Catastrophic Backtracking. The `marked.js` file contains several regular expressions that contain patterns which can be validated by a large number of variations. Meaning, if the pattern is validated in one way, and the regex engine moves on to the next pattern, only to have it not be validated, the engine then backtracks to the previous pattern and tries to validate it another way. If it succeeds again, and then fails on the next pattern again, the cycle continues, trying all of the variations to validate the pattern. An attacker can exploit this by inputting a long string containing characters which can satisfy the vulnerable pattern with a large number of variations followed by a character that does not match the next pattern. When parsed by the regex engine, this will cause uncontrolled resource consumption as the engine tries to match the entire regular expression and fails repeatedly, as it goes through all the possible variations, ultimately resulting in a Denial of Service (DoS).
deeperData.detectionMarkdown: The application is vulnerable by using this component.
deeperData.recommendationMarkdown: We recommend upgrading to a version of this component that is not vulnerable to this specific issue.

deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The `marked` component is vulnerable to a Regular Expression Denial of Service (ReDoS) attack.  When specific input is supplied to `marked`, the application will hang as it tries to process a certain regular expression against the malicious input. In a server-side, NodeJS environment, this is particularly severe as NodeJS is single-threaded. An attacker can exploit this vulnerability to cause the application process to become unresponsive, thus blocking subsequent requests from being fulfilled if used in a server-side setting.

*NOTE:* This vulnerability is the same as CVE-2017-17461 which was rejected erroneously (see https://blog.sonatype.com/cve-2017-17461-vulnerable-or-not).
deeperData.detectionMarkdown: The application is vulnerable by using this component.
deeperData.recommendationMarkdown: We recommend upgrading to a version of this component that is not vulnerable to this specific issue.

deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `marked` package is vulnerable to a Regular Expression Denial of Service (ReDoS) attack. The `token()` and `resolveUrl()` functions in the `marked.js` file use an insecure regular expression to trim whitespace characters. A remote attacker can exploit this vulnerability by supplying a URL that contains a large amount of whitespace characters before the final `/` character (i.e. `https://www.test.com${whitespace}/`). This will result in catastrophic backtracking and ultimately a DoS condition when the application attempts to process the markdown.
deeperData.detectionMarkdown: The application is vulnerable by using this component.
deeperData.recommendationMarkdown: We recommend upgrading to a version of this component that is not vulnerable to this specific issue.

deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `express` package is vulnerable to HTTP Response Splitting. The `redirect()` function in the file `response.js` allows Carriage Return and Line Feed (CRLF) characters in the user input, which is then injected into the HTTP response. A remote attacker can exploit the vulnerability by crafting user input with the CRLF characters which will allow the attacker to set arbitrary HTTP response headers and control the body of the HTTP response.  Likewise, any sensitive information, such as authentication tokens that are returned in the HTTP response sequentially after the injection point, will be accessible to the attacker.
deeperData.detectionMarkdown:
The application is vulnerable by using this component with NodeJS runtime versions less than 0.9.4.  NodeJS runtime versions including and after 0.9.4 have built in response splitting protections, effectively remediating the issue at the runtime level.
 
See [https://github.com/expressjs/express/pull/974](https://github.com/expressjs/express/pull/974) for more details.
deeperData.recommendationMarkdown:
The vulnerability was fixed at the runtime level (within NodeJS itself). Upgrading NodeJS to a version after or including 0.9.4 will remediate this issue. Using `express` versions 4.1.1 and later should be safe as these versions are incompatible with NodeJS versions earlier than 0.10.0.

Note: If this component is included as a bundled/transitive dependency of another component, there may not be an upgrade path. In this instance, we recommend contacting the maintainers who included the vulnerable package. Alternatively, we recommend investigating alternative components or a potential mitigating control.

deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `express` and `hbs` packages used together are vulnerable to Local File Read due to Path Traversal. The `render` function in `express` which internally instantiates `hbs` to read files fails to account for traversal characters. Consequently, requests to the `render` function containing an unescaped `options` parameter may result in a local file read. A remote attacker can leverage this vulnerability to read local files from unintended locations by supplying a payload with traversal characters in any field from which the affected parameter is assigned.
deeperData.detectionMarkdown:
The application is vulnerable by using both `express` and `hbs` with unescaped user supplied input passed to the `render` function in `express`.   

NOTE: This vulnerability is exploitable when both `express` and `hbs` are being used in a certain way and the `options` argument being sent to the `render` function is not being escaped (via `{ }`).  
Reference: [Blog post](https://blog.shoebpatel.com/2021/01/23/The-Secret-Parameter-LFR-and-Potential-RCE-in-NodeJS-Apps/).    

When combined with `sonatype-2019-0058`, which impacts `handlebars`, the exploit may potentially lead to Remote Code Execution (RCE).
deeperData.recommendationMarkdown:
There is no non-vulnerable upgrade path for this component/package. We recommend investigating alternative components or a potential mitigating control.
We also recommend escaping all user supplied input.

deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The `unset-value` package is vulnerable to Prototype Pollution. The `unset` function in `index.js` files allows for access to object prototype properties. An attacker can exploit this to override the behavior of object prototypes, resulting in a possible Denial of Service (DoS), Remote Code Execution (RCE), or other unexpected behavior.

NOTE: The original [linked](https://huntr.dev/bounties/1-npm-unset-value/) advisory for this vulnerability may not be accessible until it is validated by the project developer. But, proof-of-concept (PoC) tests by the Sonatype security research team revealed that `unset-value` is vulnerable to Prototype Pollution.
deeperData.detectionMarkdown: The application is vulnerable by using this component.
deeperData.recommendationMarkdown:
We recommend upgrading to a version of this component that is not vulnerable to this specific issue.

Note: If this component is included as a bundled/transitive dependency of another component, there may not be an upgrade path. In this instance, we recommend contacting the maintainers who included the vulnerable package. Alternatively, we recommend investigating alternative components or a potential mitigating control.

deeperData.description: minimist before 1.2.2 could be tricked into adding or modifying properties of Object.prototype using a "constructor" or "__proto__" payload.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The `minimist` package is vulnerable to Prototype Pollution. The `setKey` function in `index.js` modifies JavaScript objects based on user input. An attacker can exploit this behavior to modify the behavior of `Object.prototype`, causing all other objects in the code to behave in unexpected and malicious ways.

*Advisory Deviation Notice:* The Sonatype security research team discovered that the fix for this vulnerability was backported to 0.2.1 for the 0.X versions.
deeperData.detectionMarkdown: The application is vulnerable by using this component.

deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `utile` package is vulnerable to Information Disclosure.  The `encode()` and `decode()` functions in `base64.js` utilize the `Buffer()` constructor native to Node.js to initialize blocks of memory when encoding and decoding Base64-encoded strings.  This function, which may be used to process user input, does not ensure that uninitialized memory stored in the `Buffer` object is cleared before it is used in the encoding and decoding process, which may lead to the exposure of uninitialized memory.  An attacker can exploit this vulnerability by sending a request specifically designed to cause the exposure of uninitialized memory, and examining the response.  The response may contain sensitive information including encryption keys, passwords, and other information that could be leveraged by an attacker to execute further attacks.
deeperData.detectionMarkdown: The application is vulnerable by using this component.
deeperData.recommendationMarkdown: There is no non vulnerable version of this component/package. We recommend investigating alternative components or a potential mitigating control.

deeperData.description: This affects the package nconf before 0.11.4. When using the memory engine, it is possible to store a nested JSON representation of the configuration. The .set() function, that is responsible for setting the configuration properties, is vulnerable to Prototype Pollution. By providing a crafted property, it is possible to modify the properties on the Object.prototype.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `nconf` package contains a Prototype Pollution vulnerability. The `set` function in the `memory.js` file allows the addition or modification of object prototype properties via the `__proto__` accessor. A remote attacker with the ability to store a JSON object in the in-memory application storage via the affected function can exploit this vulnerability to modify the behavior of object prototypes which, depending on their use in the application, may result in a Denial of Service (DoS), Remote Code Execution (RCE), or other unexpected behavior
deeperData.detectionMarkdown: The application is vulnerable by using this component.
deeperData.recommendationMarkdown:
We recommend upgrading to a version of this component that is not vulnerable to this specific issue.

Note: If this component is included as a bundled/transitive dependency of another component, there may not be an upgrade path. In this instance, we recommend contacting the maintainers who included the vulnerable package. Alternatively, we recommend investigating alternative components or a potential mitigating control.

deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The `ms` package is vulnerable to Regular Expression Denial of Service (ReDoS). The `parse()` method in `index.js` allows strings that are significantly larger than is actually required.  A remote attacker could potentially exploit this behavior to tie up a vulnerable machine's processing power, resulting in a DoS situation.

*Note:* This vulnerability has been assigned CVE-2017-20162 and is due to an incomplete fix of CVE-2015-8315
deeperData.detectionMarkdown: The application is vulnerable by using this component.
deeperData.recommendationMarkdown:
We recommend upgrading to a version of this component that is not vulnerable to this specific issue.

Note: If this component is included as a bundled/transitive dependency of another component, there may not be an upgrade path. In this instance, we recommend contacting the maintainers who included the vulnerable package. Alternatively, we recommend investigating alternative components or a potential mitigating control.

deeperData.description: This affects the package glob-parent before 5.1.2. The enclosure regex used to check for strings ending in enclosure containing path separator.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `glob-parent` package is vulnerable to Regular Expression Denial of Service (ReDoS). The `globParent` function in the `index.js` file uses an insecure regular expression to identify strings ending in enclosures with a path separator. A remote attacker can exploit this vulnerability by supplying an input that starts with an enclosure char, such as `{` or `[` followed by a long repetitive sequence of any alphanumeric character, forward slashes or back slashes. This will lead to catastrophic backtracking and result in a Denial of Service condition when the application attempts to process the attacker-supplied data
deeperData.detectionMarkdown: The application is vulnerable by using this component.
deeperData.recommendationMarkdown:
We recommend upgrading to a version of this component that is not vulnerable to this specific issue.

Note: If this component is included as a bundled/transitive dependency of another component, there may not be an upgrade path. In this instance, we recommend contacting the maintainers who included the vulnerable package. Alternatively, we recommend investigating alternative components or a potential mitigating control.

deeperData.description: minimist before 1.2.2 could be tricked into adding or modifying properties of Object.prototype using a "constructor" or "__proto__" payload.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The `minimist` package is vulnerable to Prototype Pollution. The `setKey` function in `index.js` modifies JavaScript objects based on user input. An attacker can exploit this behavior to modify the behavior of `Object.prototype`, causing all other objects in the code to behave in unexpected and malicious ways.

*Advisory Deviation Notice:* The Sonatype security research team discovered that the fix for this vulnerability was backported to 0.2.1 for the 0.X versions.
deeperData.detectionMarkdown: The application is vulnerable by using this component.

deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `csurf` package is vulnerable to Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF). The `setCookie` and `csrfToken` functions in `index.js` implement inadequate anti-CSRF measures, allowing CSRF tokens to remain valid for the entire life of a user session. A remote attacker can exploit this behavior by submitting a previously used token to issue requests to an affected endpoint on behalf of the victim.
deeperData.detectionMarkdown: The application is vulnerable by using this component.
deeperData.recommendationMarkdown: There is no non-vulnerable upgrade path for this component/package. We recommend investigating alternative components or a potential mitigating control.

deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `csurf` package is vulnerable to Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF). The `csrf()` method in the `index.js` file only validates the Cross-Site Request Forgery token when it is provided. A remote attacker can exploit this vulnerability with a malicious web application that simply removes the CSRF token from any request it sends on a victim's behalf.
deeperData.detectionMarkdown: The application is vulnerable by using this component.
deeperData.recommendationMarkdown: The maintainer marked this package as [deprecated](https://www.npmjs.com/package/csurf). For that reason, there is no non-vulnerable upgrade path for this component/package. We recommend investigating alternative components or a potential mitigating control.

deeperData.description: This affects the package nconf before 0.11.4. When using the memory engine, it is possible to store a nested JSON representation of the configuration. The .set() function, that is responsible for setting the configuration properties, is vulnerable to Prototype Pollution. By providing a crafted property, it is possible to modify the properties on the Object.prototype.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `nconf` package contains a Prototype Pollution vulnerability. The `set` function in the `memory.js` file allows the addition or modification of object prototype properties via the `__proto__` accessor. A remote attacker with the ability to store a JSON object in the in-memory application storage via the affected function can exploit this vulnerability to modify the behavior of object prototypes which, depending on their use in the application, may result in a Denial of Service (DoS), Remote Code Execution (RCE), or other unexpected behavior
deeperData.detectionMarkdown: The application is vulnerable by using this component.
deeperData.recommendationMarkdown:
We recommend upgrading to a version of this component that is not vulnerable to this specific issue.

Note: If this component is included as a bundled/transitive dependency of another component, there may not be an upgrade path. In this instance, we recommend contacting the maintainers who included the vulnerable package. Alternatively, we recommend investigating alternative components or a potential mitigating control.

deeperData.description: minimist before 1.2.2 could be tricked into adding or modifying properties of Object.prototype using a "constructor" or "__proto__" payload.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The `minimist` package is vulnerable to Prototype Pollution. The `setKey` function in `index.js` modifies JavaScript objects based on user input. An attacker can exploit this behavior to modify the behavior of `Object.prototype`, causing all other objects in the code to behave in unexpected and malicious ways.

*Advisory Deviation Notice:* The Sonatype security research team discovered that the fix for this vulnerability was backported to 0.2.1 for the 0.X versions.
deeperData.detectionMarkdown: The application is vulnerable by using this component.

deeperData.description: decode-uri-component 0.2.0 is vulnerable to Improper Input Validation resulting in DoS.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `decode-uri-component` package is vulnerable to Denial of Service (DoS) attacks. The `decode()` function in `index.js` includes a call to the non-existent `join()` function of a `decodeComponents` object, leading to a `TypeError` being thrown. An attacker can exploit this vulnerability by supplying a crafted string (for example, `%ea%ba%5a%ba`) to the `decode()` function, which will result in an uncaught exception and a potential DoS condition.
deeperData.detectionMarkdown: The application is vulnerable by using this component if the application allows untrusted user input to be passed to the `decode()` function of `decode-uri-component`.
deeperData.recommendationMarkdown:
We recommend upgrading to a version of this component that is not vulnerable to this specific issue.

Note: If this component is included as a bundled/transitive dependency of another component, there may not be an upgrade path. In this instance, we recommend contacting the maintainers who included the vulnerable package. Alternatively, we recommend investigating alternative components or a potential mitigating control.

deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `debug` package is vulnerable to Regular Expression Denial of Service (ReDoS). The `node.js` file uses an improper regular expression that allows for an immense number of possible matching paths to be evaluated in order to find a match. A remote attacker can provide a specially crafted input which contains very long sequences of whitespace and newline characters, to the `o` formatter. When evaluated, the regular expression engine will take a long time to parse the input and eventually consume all of the available CPU resources, resulting in Denial of Service (DoS).
deeperData.detectionMarkdown: The application is vulnerable by using this component.
deeperData.recommendationMarkdown: We recommend upgrading to a version of this component that is not vulnerable to this specific issue.

deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The `parse_js_number(num)` method in `lib/parse.js` of the `uglify-js` package (a JavaScript tokenizer / parser / beautifier / compressor toolkit) running  under `node.js` does not properly handle validation of a long string appended with an invalid decimal, such as `.1ee7`,  resulting in a regular expression denial of service (ReDoS). An attacker can exploit this vulnerability by providing a specially crafted Javascript file as input to the parser causing the program to hang upon processing it.

**NOTE:** CVE-2015-8858 has been assigned to this vulnerability.
deeperData.detectionMarkdown: The application is vulnerable if using this package and you are accepting untrusted Javascript files to be processed by `uglify-js` as part of the application's functionality.
deeperData.recommendationMarkdown:
We recommend upgrading to a version of this component that is not vulnerable to this specific issue.

Note: If this component is included as a bundled/transitive dependency of another component, there may not be an upgrade path. In this instance, we recommend contacting the maintainers who included the vulnerable package. Alternatively, we recommend investigating alternative components or a potential mitigating control.

deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `revalidator` package contains a Regular Expression Denial of Service (ReDoS) vulnerability. The `validateProperty` function in the `revalidator.js` file uses an insecure regular expression to validate URL format extensions. A remote attacker can exploit this vulnerability by crafting a request containing a url that starts with a valid protocol, `(https|ftp|git)://`, followed by a long repetitive sequence of dot separated numeric characters. This will trigger catastrophic backtracking and result in a Denial of Service condition once the application attempts to process the attacker supplied data.
deeperData.detectionMarkdown: The application is vulnerable by using this component with the `validateFormatExtensions` options set to `true`, which is the default behavior.
deeperData.recommendationMarkdown: There is no non-vulnerable upgrade path for this component/package. We recommend investigating alternative components or a potential mitigating control.
